choices.text: Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia

questions.text: A G2P1 at 17 weeks presented to the OPD with a BP of 148/90 mmHg. Six hours later, her BP is 142/90 mmHg. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic HTN

 

In pregnancy, the timing of hypertension onset is critical in determining the diagnosis. Chronic hypertension is defined as high blood pressure that is present before pregnancy or that is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's blood pressure readings of 148/90 mmHg and 142/90 mmHg at 17 weeks of gestation indicate hypertension occurring before the 20-week threshold, fitting the definition of chronic hypertension.

 

To confirm chronic hypertension, if the patient's blood pressure remains elevated 12 weeks postpartum, the diagnosis is solidified.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preeclampsia: This is incorrect because preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension that develops after 20 weeks of gestation and is accompanied by proteinuria. This patient's hypertension was noted before 20 weeks and there is no mention of proteinuria.

 

Option B. Gestational HTN: This option is incorrect as gestational hypertension also develops after 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's hypertension was detected at 17 weeks, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia: This is incorrect because superimposed preeclampsia would require evidence of new-onset proteinuria or worsening hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation in a patient with pre-existing chronic hypertension. There is no mention of proteinuria in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation in a pregnant woman is most likely chronic hypertension.

questions.text: A diabetic patient was advised exercise by the treating physician. The glucose transporter which is insulin sensitive is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glut 4

 

Glucose transporter 4 (Glut 4) is the insulin-sensitive glucose transporter found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle. Insulin plays a key role in regulating glucose uptake in these tissues by promoting the translocation of Glut 4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane, thereby enhancing glucose entry into the cell. This insulin-mediated mechanism is crucial in maintaining blood glucose levels, especially during states of increased energy demand, such as exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glut 1: This glucose transporter is found in nearly all tissues, including the brain, and facilitates the basal uptake of glucose independently of insulin. It is not insulin-sensitive.

 

Option B. Glut 2: Glut 2 is mainly present in liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the renal tubules, where it helps regulate glucose levels.

 

Option C. Glut 3: This transporter is primarily located in neurons and the placenta, ensuring high-affinity glucose uptake in tissues with high glucose demand. It is not regulated by insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glut 4 is the only glucose transporter that is insulin-sensitive, primarily found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle, where it facilitates glucose uptake in response to insulin.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unstable Angina

 

The patient's presentation includes chest pain unrelieved by nitroglycerin (NTG), stable vitals, and normal cardiac enzymes. The provided ECG is normal, showing no signs of ST elevation or ischemic changes such as ST depression or T wave inversion.

 

Unstable Angina involves chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion, and normal cardiac enzymes. The patient has multiple risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, aortic sclerosis), and the fact that his chest pain did not respond to NTG and his enzymes are normal strongly suggests unstable angina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. STEMI: STEMI is characterized by ST elevation on ECG and elevated cardiac enzymes indicating myocardial necrosis. This patient's ECG shows no ST elevation, and his cardiac enzymes are normal, making STEMI unlikely.

 

Option B. NSTEMI: NSTEMI would present with elevated cardiac enzymes due to myocardial damage, despite the absence of ST elevation. This patient’s normal enzyme levels exclude NSTEMI.

 

Option C. Stable Angina: Stable angina presents with chest pain that is typically relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient’s chest pain persisted despite taking NTG, indicating that stable angina is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs at rest or with minimal exertion, does not respond to nitroglycerin, and is associated with normal cardiac enzyme levels.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the association between the consumption of vegetarian/non-vegetarian food with certain diseases. The incidence of disease was evaluated in those two groups. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used when evaluating the association between categorical variables, such as the consumption of vegetarian or non-vegetarian food and the incidence of certain diseases. This study involves comparing the occurrence of diseases in two groups (vegetarians vs. non-vegetarians), which represents qualitative data.

 

The Chi-square test is specifically designed for non-parametric data (data that does not follow a normal distribution) and is ideal for comparing proportions, percentages, or counts between two or more groups. In this context, the test helps determine whether there is a significant association between diet type and disease occurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Paired student’s t-test: The paired student’s t-test is used for comparing means within the same group at two different times (before and after an intervention). It is suitable for continuous data, not for comparing categorical data between two distinct groups.

 

Option B. Unpaired student’s t-test: The unpaired student’s t-test compares the means of two independent groups, such as test scores or measurements. This test is used for continuous, normally distributed data and is not suitable for categorical or qualitative data like the incidence of diseases.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon test: The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric test used for comparing two paired groups when the data is not normally distributed. It is similar to the paired t-test but for ordinal or continuous data, making it unsuitable for categorical data such as disease incidence.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chi-square test is used to determine the association between categorical variables, especially when comparing the incidence of outcomes across two or more independent groups.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a past history of intubation presents to the OPD with shortness of breath that began during play, approximately 2 months after the intubation. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Croup

 

Explanation: 


The presentation suggests croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) because:

 

  • X-ray shows characteristic "steeple sign" (subglottic narrowing)
  • Age group is typical (6 months to 3 years)
  • History of recent intubation could predispose to viral infection

  • Clinical features match with croup: 

    • Gradual onset of respiratory distress
    • Inspiratory stridor
    • Usually caused by parainfluenza virus types I & II
    • Submucosal edema causes narrowing in subglottic region

     

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis

 

  • Shows "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray
  • More severe, rapid onset
  • Typically caused by H. influenzae
  • Child prefers sitting position (tripod sign)

 

 

Option C. Laryngomalacia

 

  • Most common congenital anomaly of larynx
  • Shows omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy
  • Symptoms improve in prone position
  • Present from birth

 

 

Option D. Bronchitis

 

  • Lower airway inflammation
  • No characteristic "steeple sign"
  • Different radiological findings
  • Usually presents with cough as primary symptom

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"steeple sign" on chest/neck X-ray as characteristic of croup, representing subglottic narrowing.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

 

Systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma, is characterized by fibrosis and tightening of the skin, particularly on the face and extremities. The presence of numbness in the fingertips is often due to Raynaud's phenomenon, which is common in systemic sclerosis and results from vasospasm and ischemia.

 

The positive ANA test with a nucleolar pattern is highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis. This pattern is seen in more than 95% of patients with scleroderma. Specific antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis include anti-centromere antibodies (often found in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis) and anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies (associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also present with positive ANA, but the nucleolar pattern is not typically associated with Sjogren's. The physical findings of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Option C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms and often includes positive ANA. However, the nucleolar pattern is less common in SLE. The characteristic features of SLE include malar rash, arthritis, and serositis, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, causing chronic inflammatory polyarthritis. While ANA can be positive in rheumatoid arthritis, the nucleolar pattern and symptoms of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining the placenta and notices that the side she is holding has the umbilical cord and vessels. This side is the: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal side

 

The fetal side of the placenta is characterized by the presence of the umbilical cord insertion and visible branching blood vessels (chorionic vessels) radiating from it beneath the transparent amnion. This surface is smooth and shiny due to the amniotic membrane covering it. The umbilical cord contains fetal blood vessels that branch out across this surface, forming a network that facilitates nutrient and gas exchange between mother and fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maternal side: Incorrect because the maternal side has a rough, cobblestone appearance with 15-20 cotyledons. It does not have the umbilical cord attachment.

 

Option C. Decidual surface: Incorrect because this is another name for the maternal side of the placenta. It has an irregular surface with visible cotyledons and does not contain the umbilical cord.

 

Option D. Basal surface: Incorrect because this is also another term for the maternal side of the placenta. Like the decidual surface, it refers to the rough side that was attached to the uterine wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fetal side of the placenta can be identified by:

 

  • Presence of umbilical cord insertion
  • Visible branching blood vessels (chorionic vessels)
  • Smooth, shiny surface due to amniotic membrane covering

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Trauma to the proximal neck of fibula leads to injury of the common peroneal nerve as the nerve winds around the neck of fibula.
  • The CPN injury causes paralysis of muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, EHL, peroneus tertius (deep peroneal nerve), peroneal longus and brevis (superficial peroneal nerve).
  • Paralysis of these muscles causes failure of foot dorsiflexion i.e., foot drop.

 

 

  • There is also sensory loss on the anterior and lateral sides of the leg, dorsum of the foot and toes, and medial side of the big toe.
  • Lateral border of the foot and lateral side of the little toe are unaffected (supplied by sural nerve, formed by tibial nerve).
  • Medial border of the foot and ball of big toe are also unaffected (supplied by saphenous nerve, branch of femoral nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral malleolus: Fracture at the lateral malleolus is Danis-Weber type A fracture of the ankle. In this, there is fracture of the lateral malleolus distal to the syndesmosis. It is usually a stable fracture. It is generally below the tibial plafond, with an intact syndesmosis and deltoid ligament. This fracture does not cause any nerve injury; thus no ankle movement is affected. This fracture has a good prognosis with ankle secured in a splint or cast.

 

Option B. Proximal tibia: Fracture of proximal third of tibia is associated with anterior knee pain (cases operated with intramedullary nailing), non-union, malunion. No nerve is injured with this type of fracture.

 

Option D. Tibial shaft: Tibial shaft fractures rarely cause nerve injury. Surgical fixation of the fracture with plating puts the superficial peroneal nerve at risk. Saphenous nerve can be injured during placement of locking screws. Transient peroneal nerve palsy after closed nailing can cause EHL weakness and decreased sensation of first dorsal webspace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the  cord as shown in the image. The cord snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • Manual removal of placenta:
    • The maneuver shown in the image is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, used in controlled cord traction for the delivery of the placenta.
    • If the umbilical cord snaps during this maneuver, it indicates a retained placenta, which can lead to profuse bleeding.
    • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta to prevent excessive hemorrhage and ensure that no parts of the placenta remain in the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: While oxytocin is used to enhance uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage, in this scenario, it is more critical to address the retained placenta immediately through manual removal.

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is beneficial in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding, but it will not resolve the issue of the retained placenta.

 

Option C. Arrange blood and Crede’s method: Arranging blood is prudent for managing potential blood loss, but Crede’s method, which involves expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure, is not recommended due to the risk of uterine inversion and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction for placenta delivery, manual removal of the placenta is the immediate next step to prevent hemorrhage and ensure complete removal.

 

Ref: Page 1298, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and white line of Frenkel on X-ray? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Vitamin C is crucial for the absorption of iron in the body as it converts ferric ion (Fe³⁺) to ferrous ion (Fe²⁺), the form in which iron is best absorbed in the intestine. A deficiency of vitamin C can impair iron absorption, leading to iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, vitamin C is essential for the post-translational modification of collagen, where proline is converted to hydroxyproline and lysine to hydroxylysine. This modification strengthens collagen fibers; without sufficient vitamin C, collagen becomes weak, leading to symptoms such as bleeding gums due to fragile blood vessels. The white line of Frenkel on X-ray is another characteristic sign of scurvy, a condition resulting from severe vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia (low neutrophil count), and hypopigmentation, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the specific X-ray findings mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron deficiency leads to anemia, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the white line of Frenkel on X-ray, which are specific to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Zinc: Zinc deficiency is associated with delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, and immune dysfunction, but it does not cause the symptoms outlined in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and the white line of Frenkel on X-ray due to impaired iron absorption and defective collagen synthesis.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought to the hospital with burn injuries on the right side of the body, including the upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg, mostly on the front. What is the estimated burn percentage? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate the burn percentage in infants, the Lund & Browder chart is used.

 

  • In children surface area of Head is more, and  Lower limbs less as compared to adults:
    • Head is “18% - Age”; 
    • Each lower limb is “14% + (0.5 X Age)”
  • Above rule applicable till about 9 years of age (because after that almost similar to adults, so rule of 9 can be used)
  • Other Body Parts (Trunks, Upper limbs): same proportion of body in child as that of Adults
  • So in a 1 year child:
    • Head: 18%- 1= 17% (Front 8.5% + Back 8.5%)
    • Each Lower limb: 14% + 0.5 (1)= 14.5% (Front 7.25% + Back 7.25%) 
    • Chest: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Abdomen: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Each Upper limb: 9% (Front 4.5% + Back 4.5%): Same As Adults

    • Perinium: 1%: Same As Adults

       

Calculating Burn Area for the Right Side (Front Only) for a 1 year child

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-10% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is too low.

 

Option C. 25-35% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is high.

 

Option D. >50% : Incorrect. This would require extensive burns covering most of the body, which is not observed in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants, the burn percentage is calculated differently than in adults, using the Lund & Browder chart. In this case, burns affecting the only right side of body and only on front on upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg contribute to 15-25% total body surface area (TBSA)​

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start LMWH.
Stop warfarin and start heparin.
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy 4mg/ day. What is the appropriate next step in management. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH.

 

Explanation:

 

Stop warfarin and start LMWH: Warfarin is teratogenic and has a significant risk of causing warfarin embryopathy, particularly in doses greater than 5mg per day. In pregnancy, it is recommended to change warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) in the first trimester, especially if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/day. After 13 weeks, it can be switched back to warfarin until delivery. Near delivery, warfarin should again be replaced by LMWH or UFH to manage the risk of bleeding complications during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: This option is partially correct as it aligns with the practice of switching from warfarin to a safer anticoagulant near delivery. However, the preferred anticoagulant in this situation is LMWH due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and ease of administration.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: This is incorrect because continuing warfarin at 36 weeks of gestation poses significant risks of fetal hemorrhage and warfarin embryopathy. It is essential to switch to a safer anticoagulant like LMWH or UFH close to delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: While this option includes stopping warfarin and starting LMWH, which is correct, the addition of aspirin is only indicated in women who are at a very high risk of thrombosis. The general recommendation does not include aspirin unless there is a specific high-risk indication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin should be replaced by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) near delivery to manage the risks associated with its teratogenic effects and potential complications during delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 2404, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A young female reports episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. Which of the following acid-base disturbances is she most likely to have? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

 

The case is suggestive of bulimia nervosa with purging behavior (self-induced vomiting). This leads to:

 

  • Loss of gastric acid (HCl) through repeated vomiting
  • Loss of chloride ions leading to hypochloremia
  • Loss of potassium leading to hypokalemia
  • The combined loss of acid and electrolytes results in metabolic alkalosis This condition is specifically characterized as hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to the loss of acid and electrolytes through repeated purging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect because this occurs due to CO2 retention from respiratory problems, not from purging behavior. Self-induced vomiting doesn't affect the respiratory system directly.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect because this results from hyperventilation leading to excessive CO2 loss, not from purging behavior. The acid-base disturbance here is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because purging through vomiting causes loss of acid, not accumulation. Metabolic acidosis occurs when there's excess acid retention or bicarbonate loss, which isn't the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia Nervosa

questions.text: The 1st sign to be seen in Mg toxicity in a patient receiving MgSO4 for eclampsia is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)

 

The correct answer is Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes). When administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for eclampsia, it is crucial to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity. The first clinical sign indicating toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes.

 

Detailed Explanation:

 

  • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. While effective, it has a narrow therapeutic range, making monitoring for toxicity essential.
  • Monitoring Signs:
    • Loss of DTRs: This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact.
    • Respiratory Depression: Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise.
    • Cardiac Arrest: In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac arrhythmias: While significant, this is a later sign of magnesium toxicity and typically occurs after respiratory depression.

 

Option B. Hypotonia: This can be a symptom of magnesium toxicity but is not the first sign observed.

 

Option D. Respiratory depression: This follows the loss of deep tendon reflexes and is a critical sign of advancing magnesium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs) is the first clinical sign of magnesium toxicity in patients receiving MgSO4 for eclampsia. Continuous monitoring of DTRs is crucial to detect early toxicity and prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-45 dB

 

The given clinical scenario of hearing loss with a negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz and positive Rinne at 1024 Hz indicates air conduction and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

 

  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz tuning fork (TF) but positive for 512Hz tuning fork → approximate hearing loss will be 20-30dB.
  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz & 512Hz TF but positive for 1024Hz TF → approximate hearing loss will be 30–45dB
  • Rinne’s negative for all 256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz → approximate hearing loss will be 45-60dB.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient has just undergone surgery and requires a drug to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during the procedure. Which of the following drugs is used for this purpose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is the correct answer because it is commonly used to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during surgeries. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down acetylcholine. By inhibiting this enzyme, neostigmine increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which counteracts the effects of muscle relaxants used during surgery.

 

In clinical practice, neostigmine is often administered alongside atropine. This combination is used to mitigate the cholinergic side effects (such as bradycardia) that can occur due to the increased acetylcholine levels. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, helps prevent these unwanted side effects by blocking the action of acetylcholine on the heart and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bethanechol: Bethanechol is a cholinergic drug used primarily to treat urinary retention and is not used to reverse muscle relaxation induced during surgery.

 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug and is used to prevent the side effects of neostigmine rather than to reverse muscle relaxation itself.

 

Option D. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor but is generally used for diagnosing myasthenia gravis rather than reversing muscle relaxation in the surgical setting. Neostigmine is preferred in this context due to its longer duration of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reversal agents:

 

  • Neostigmine is commonly used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants after surgery. It works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, and is combined with atropine to prevent cholinergic side effects.
  • Sugammadex: Known as a Selective Relaxant Binding Agent (SRBA). Specifically used to reverse the effects of Rocuronium and Vecuronium. It is the fastest acting reversal agent and does not cause cholinergic side effects, eliminating the need for atropine.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of cholecystectomy 4 years back for gallstones presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a stone in the common bile duct. What is the most probable type of stone causing this obstruction? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary  

 

The classification of common bile duct (CBD) stones helps determine the probable type and origin of the stones.

 

  • Primary bile duct stones, also known as primary choledocholithiasis, form directly within the bile duct. They are distinct from gallbladder stones.
  • Their formation is typically associated with bile stasis, infection, or parasitic infestation of the bile ducts, particularly the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis, which is endemic in some parts of Asia.
  •  These stones are often pigmented.
  •  The fact that this patient developed a stone in the common bile duct following a cholecystectomy >2 years back suggests the stone might be a primary stone, forming due to some underlying bile duct pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary: Secondary bile duct stones, or secondary choledocholithiasis, refer to gallstones that formed in the gallbladder and then migrated into the bile duct. This is the most common cause of bile duct stones in patients who still have their gallbladders. Secondary stones are typically cholesterol stones, being yellowish and softer than primary stones.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary stones are essentially advanced secondary stones. They are stones that have resided in the ductal system for a long time after migrating from the gallbladder, and over time, they might undergo changes due to recurrent bouts of cholangitis or prolonged bile stasis.

 

Option D. Retained: Retained stones refer to stones that were overlooked or missed during an initial procedure, like a cholecystectomy. They should be diagnosed within 2 years of cholecystectomy. They remain in the bile duct and can later cause symptoms. These stones were originally in the gallbladder or bile duct at the time of surgery and were not adequately removed or were missed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary bile duct stones form directly within the bile ducts and are associated with underlying bile duct pathology.
  • They are different from secondary stones, which form in the gallbladder and migrate into the bile duct, and retained stones, which are missed during the initial surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding increase in GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase renal perfusion

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is influenced by various factors, including the blood flow through the kidneys and the pressures within the glomerular capillaries. An increase in renal perfusion means an increase in blood flow to the kidneys, which enhances the filtration process and thereby increases the GFR. This can be achieved by dilation of the afferent arteriole (which increases blood flow into the glomerulus) or by constriction of the efferent arteriole (which increases the pressure within the glomerulus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase resistance of afferent arteriole: Increasing the resistance of the afferent arteriole means constricting it, which would reduce blood flow into the glomerulus and subsequently decrease the GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease resistance of efferent arteriole: Decreasing the resistance of the efferent arteriole means dilating it, allowing blood to flow out of the glomerulus more easily. This reduces the pressure within the glomerulus, leading to a decrease in GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increasing the hydrostatic pressure within the Bowman's capsule would oppose the filtration pressure, leading to a decrease in GFR rather than an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing renal perfusion is the most effective way to increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High median nerve

 

The symptoms described in the question indicate involvement of the median nerve, particularly the high median nerve. The high median nerve innervates the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, controls thumb movement, and supplies the thenar muscles responsible for thumb functions. Injury to this nerve can lead to sensory loss and motor deficits, such as difficulty moving the thumb and thenar atrophy, as mentioned in the question. The presence of sensory loss, along with thenar atrophy, strongly indicates a high median nerve injury, rather than its branches like the anterior interosseous nerve, which does not affect sensory perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies the medial side of the hand, including the little finger and half of the ring finger. It does not innervate the lateral 3 ½ fingers or the thenar muscles. Therefore, an injury to the ulnar nerve would not present with the described sensory and motor deficits.

 

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and provides sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand. It does not supply the thenar muscles or the palmar side of the fingers described in the question. Hence, it cannot be the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve: This nerve is a deep branch of the median nerve, which primarily supplies deep muscles in the forearm like the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of the flexor digitorum profundus. It does not carry sensory fibers, so it would not cause sensory loss or thenar atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: A patient had enlarging nodules present on his scalp. He was taking prednisolone, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus. His clinical lesion and the histopathological lesion are shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malakoplakia

 

The patient's clinical history and biopsy findings suggest a diagnosis of Malakoplakia. Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition that is often associated with immunosuppressive states, such as in patients taking medications like prednisolone, mycophenolate, and tacrolimus.

 

The characteristic histopathological feature of Malakoplakia is the presence of Michaelis-Guttmann bodies, which are basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions with a "targetoid" appearance seen in macrophages.

 

These bodies result from incomplete phagocytosis and subsequent calcium and iron deposition.

 

Malakoplakia commonly affects the urinary bladder but can also present in other organs, including the skin, as seen in this patient with scalp lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis would typically present with caseating granulomas, which are not seen in the provided histopathological image. The characteristic Michaelis-Guttmann bodies in this image rule out tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Pyoderma gangrenosum: This condition is usually associated with painful ulcerative skin lesions and does not present with the histopathological findings seen here. Pyoderma gangrenosum is not associated with Michaelis-Guttmann bodies.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lesion: Drug-induced skin lesions generally present with nonspecific inflammation or necrosis rather than granulomatous inflammation with the distinct Michaelis-Guttmann bodies characteristic of Malakoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition marked by Michaelis-Guttmann bodies and is often seen in immunosuppressed patients. It can affect organs beyond the urinary bladder, including the skin.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pouch of Douglas

 

The arrow in the image points to the pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch. It is located between the rectum posteriorly and the uterus anteriorly in females. This is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in the supine position. The pouch of Douglas is clinically significant as it is a common site for collection of pathological fluids like pus, blood, or malignant cells due to its dependent position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicouterine pouch: This is incorrect as the vesicouterine pouch is located between the bladder and uterus anteriorly, not between the rectum and uterus as shown in the image.

 

Option B. Morrison's pouch: This is incorrect as Morrison's pouch (hepatorenal pouch) is located between the liver and right kidney in the upper abdomen, not in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Supravesical fossa: This is a small peritoneal depression located above the bladder, but it is not a significant space for fluid accumulation compared to the Pouch of Douglas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pouch of Douglas is the rectouterine pouch, the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in females, where pathological fluid collections are often found during clinical evaluation.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

 

Explanation

 

  • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter:
    • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.

 

Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.

 

Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Interstitial lung disease
Scleroderma renal crisis

questions.text: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal dysmotility

 

Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), particularly as part of the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). This condition involves abnormalities in the motility of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulties in swallowing and gastroesophageal reflux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myopathy: While myopathy can occur in systemic sclerosis, it is not specifically more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis compared to the diffuse type.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): ILD is actually more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis due to broader and more aggressive skin involvement and higher prevalence of specific autoantibodies like Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase).

 

Option D. Scleroderma renal crisis: This is a severe complication more frequently seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, particularly in the early stages of the disease, often exacerbated by the use of corticosteroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ Chap 360

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower limb wound as shown. The wound had healthy granulation tissue. What will be used as a cover? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Split thickness skin graft

 

The correct answer is Split thickness skin graft (STSG). STSG is the preferred choice for covering a large, healing wound with healthy granulation tissue, such as a burn or degloving injury. It involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site and applying it to the wound. This type of graft covers large areas and is effective in promoting wound healing with adequate tissue coverage while maintaining flexibility. It is generally used on body areas where cosmesis is less of a priority compared to the face, which would require a full thickness graft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Full thickness skin graft: This graft involves both the epidermis and the entire dermis and is typically used for areas requiring greater cosmetic outcomes, such as the face. It is not generally used for large wounds with healthy granulation tissue, as STSG would suffice and cover larger areas with a better healing outcome.

 

Option C.  VAC dressing: Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used for non-healing or chronic wounds that require additional stimulation for granulation tissue formation and wound contraction. It is not needed when the wound already has healthy granulation tissue and is progressing well in healing.

 

Option D.  Flap: A flap is used when there is a need for bulk tissue to cover a deep or complex wound that involves structures like bone, tendons, or joints. Since the wound described has healthy granulation tissue and is not deep, a flap is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Split thickness skin grafts are the best choice for covering large, healthy granulating wounds, particularly in areas where cosmesis is not the primary concern.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

  • The image shows swan neck deformity seen in RA.
  • Characteristic Deformities of Hand and Foot In RA:

 

 

 

 

Finger deformities in RA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand. Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma. Scleroderma is a severe CTD characterized by vascular, immune and fibrotic changes in the skin and internal organs. While tethering of the skin is the clinical hallmark of SSc, many patients develop musculoskeletal symptoms also. Manifestations may include rheumatic complaints ranging from arthralgias to frank arthritis, contractures and tendon friction rubs. Articular involvement contributes to disability and impaired quality of life. All joints may be affected, although the fingers (in particular the MCP and PIP joints), wrists and ankles predominate. As the disease progresses, there is tethering and contracture of the joints with impairment of movement and function.

 

 

Calcinosis and contracture of joints

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoid

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for producing different types of hormones. The mnemonic "GFR" can help remember the order and function of these zones:

 

  • Zona glomerulosa: Produces mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone), which are involved in regulating salt and water balance.
  • Zona fasciculata: Produces glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol), which play a key role in glucose metabolism, stress response, and immune function.
  • Zona reticularis: Produces androgens (e.g., dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione), which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

The zona fasciculata specifically secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which is involved in various physiological processes including metabolism, immune response, and stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mineralocorticoid: This hormone is produced by the zona glomerulosa, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option C. Androgen: These hormones are produced by the zona reticularis, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is produced by the adrenal medulla, not the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex is responsible for producing glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol.

questions.text: Which metabolic product is responsible for causing cataract in a patient with a long-standing history of diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol

 

Explanation: 

 

In patients with long-standing diabetes, excess glucose metabolism leads to cataract formation through the sorbitol pathway:

 

  1. Excess glucose is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase
  2. Normally, sorbitol would be further metabolized to fructose, but in diabetes: 
    • The lens lacks sufficient sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme
    • Sorbitol accumulates inside the lens
    • Causes osmotic stress and water accumulation
    • Leads to membrane damage and cataract formation

 

The mechanism involves:

 

  • Accumulation of sorbitol
  • Increased osmotic pressure
  • Fluid collection in lens
  • Structural damage to lens proteins

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Galactitol: Incorrect. While similar to sorbitol, galactitol is not the primary metabolic product causing diabetic cataracts.

 

Option B. Fructose: Incorrect. Fructose is a potential end product of sorbitol metabolism, not the primary cause of diabetic cataract formation.

 

Option D. Mannitol: Incorrect. Mannitol is a sugar alcohol used as a diuretic, not involved in the diabetic cataract formation process.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, sorbitol accumulation in the lens due to insufficient enzyme activity leads to osmotic stress and cataract formation through the aldose reductase pathway.

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurons

 

Explanation:

 

Neurons (Central nervous system) are the least affected by irradiation among the options given, due to their highly differentiated and non-dividing nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Spermatogonia: These are germ cells that continually divide and are highly sensitive to radiation, which can lead to infertility.

 

Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells: These cells have a high turnover rate, making them very sensitive to radiation, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells: These cells are among the most sensitive to radiation due to their role in rapidly producing new blood cells, leading to potential marrow suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Setting up cobalt therapy units

 

The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was drawn up for the cooperative economic development of South and South-East Asia. It included 20 countries with the main aim of improving the living standards of people. The plan focused on industrial and agricultural development and provided support for health promotion, mostly through fellowships.

 

Key Contributions of the Colombo Plan:

 

  • AIIMS, New Delhi: Established with financial assistance from New Zealand.
  • Cobalt Therapy Units: Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India as part of the Colombo Plan. These units significantly enhanced the capabilities for cancer treatment in India.

 

Cobalt Therapy Units:

 

  • Cobalt Therapy: Involves using gamma rays from cobalt-60 isotopes to treat cancer. It was a crucial development in radiotherapy in the mid-20th century and improved cancer treatment outcomes significantly.
  • Provision under Colombo Plan: The supply of cobalt therapy units by Canada helped Indian medical institutions upgrade their cancer treatment facilities, making advanced radiotherapy accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, significantly enhancing the country's capacity to provide advanced cancer treatment through radiotherapy. This was a crucial step in improving healthcare infrastructure and cancer treatment capabilities in India.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Weight gain

 

Olanzapine is known to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects. In fact, among atypical antipsychotics, olanzapine causes the second-highest weight gain (after clozapine). This metabolic side effect is often a major reason for treatment discontinuation in patients, especially young women who may be concerned about body image and health implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia (TD): Incorrect because atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a very low propensity for causing tardive dyskinesia compared to typical antipsychotics. Olanzapine in particular has a very low propensity for TD.

 

Option C. Acute dystonia: Incorrect because acute dystonia is usually caused by typical antipsychotics, particularly with parenteral administration. It is unlikely with olanzapine.

 

Option D. Akathisia: Incorrect because among atypical antipsychotics, aripiprazole is more likely to cause akathisia. Olanzapine is not particularly associated with this side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weight gain is a significant side effect of olanzapine (second highest among atypical antipsychotics after clozapine) and is often a major reason for treatment non-compliance, especially in young patients.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal edema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Terlipressin plus albumin

 

The patient described has cirrhosis with signs of renal dysfunction, which suggests the possibility of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) (Remember - HRS is the diagnosis of exclusion)

 

HRS is a type of renal failure that occurs in patients with advanced liver disease and is characterized by functional renal failure due to reduced renal blood flow.

 

The initial management for suspected HRS involves stopping all diuretics, as they can exacerbate renal dysfunction.

 

The mainstay of treatment includes the administration of albumin to expand plasma volume and vasoconstrictors to improve renal blood flow. Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor that is commonly used in combination with albumin to manage HRS. This combination helps to improve renal function by counteracting the splanchnic vasodilation that occurs in cirrhosis, thereby increasing effective arterial blood volume and renal perfusion.

 

Doses – The prescribed dose of albumin is 1 gram per kilogram of body weight per day. The maximum dose should not exceed 100 grams per day. Albumin should be administered for at least 48 hours, equivalent to 2 days.

 

It's important to avoid using normal saline or lactated solutions concurrently because they contain sodium, which could be contraindicated or undesirable in the treatment circumstances requiring albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid and is not indicated in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome. It is used for conditions such as autoimmune hepatitis or severe alcoholic hepatitis, but it does not address the pathophysiology of HRS.

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant and is not appropriate in this setting due to the increased risk of bleeding in patients with cirrhosis. It is used for preventing or treating thrombotic conditions but does not play a role in managing HRS.

 

Option C. Torsemide: Torsemide is a loop diuretic and should be discontinued in patients with HRS. Diuretics can worsen renal function in these patients by further decreasing renal perfusion and exacerbating the underlying problem of splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with cirrhosis and suspected hepatorenal syndrome, the appropriate management includes the use of albumin combined with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin to improve renal function and address the underlying hemodynamic changes associated with HRS.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Patient presenting with a history of fever and cough for 5 days suggests diagnosis pneumonia. The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

 

Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

 

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with respiratory distress, coughing, and an inability to speak after eating. What is the next best step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

 Bronchoscopy is the best next step because:

 

  • Child has already presented to the hospital with respiratory distress
  • Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic
  • Allows direct visualization of the foreign body
  • Enables safe removal under controlled conditions
  • Most appropriate for hospital setting where proper equipment and expertise are available
  • Prevents complications from blind maneuvers

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Heimlich maneuver

 

  • More appropriate for immediate first aid in community setting
  • Better suited for adults than children
  • Risk of complications in young children
  • Not the best choice once patient is in hospital

 

Option C. Blind finger sweep

 

  • Contraindicated in children
  • Risk of pushing foreign body further down
  • Can cause trauma to oropharynx
  • May worsen the situation

 

Option D. Endotracheal intubation

 

  • Risk of pushing foreign body further down
  • Doesn't address removal of foreign body
  • May complicate the situation
  • Not appropriate without first visualizing foreign body

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recognize that rigid bronchoscopy is the definitive management for foreign body aspiration in a hospital setting as it allows both diagnosis and therapeutic removal.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

OPTION B: Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic feature of alkaptonuria.
