questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient visits you with inflammatory alopecia. This type of hair loss is commonly associated with which variant of tinea capitis infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favus and Kerion

 

Favus and kerion are the inflammatory variants of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms:  Zoophilic dermatophytes i.e., T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum àGriseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Endothrix and Favus and Option D: Kerion and Endothrix Endothrix infections involve the growth of fungi within the hair shaft without external spore formation and typically present with less inflammation compared to Kerion and Favus.

 

Option B: Ectothrix and Endothrix Ectothrix infections, where the fungus grows on the outside of the hair shaft and breaks the hair off at the scalp surface, are typically associated with non-inflammatory forms of alopecia such as the 'grey patch' type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory alopecia is commonly associated with the favus and kerion variants of tinea capitis, which can cause scarring and permanent hair loss due to the significant inflammatory response.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 32.39-40, 89.35

questions.text: Identify the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subhepatic space

 

  1. The right subhepatic space is a deep space located in Rutherford Morison's pouch between the liver, transverse colon, and hepatic flexure. It is a common site of intra-abdominal abscess (second to pelvis).
  2. Abscesses in the right subhepatic space may occur due to conditions such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcer, or as a complication of upper abdominal surgery.
    • Also known as Rutherford Morison's pouch, the subhepatic space is situated between the liver's posterior surface and the right kidney's anterior surface.
    • It's a potential space that can collect fluid or pus.
    • It is a common site for abscess formation, especially after conditions like appendicitis, where the infection can spread upwards into this space.
    • Due to its anatomical location and the potential for infections like appendicitis to spread to this region, the subhepatic space is recognized as the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peri splenic space: The peri-splenic space is located around the spleen and is bounded by the diaphragm, stomach, and the splenic flexure of the colon. Abscesses in this space can arise from a splenic infection or trauma, but it is not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Option B. Left subphrenic space: The left subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the spleen/stomach. It's a potential space for abscess formation, especially after splenic surgeries or gastric surgeries. However, it's not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses compared to the right side.

 

Option C. Right subphrenic space: The right subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the liver. Abscesses in this space can arise due to infections that spread from the liver or gallbladder, or after surgeries involving these organs. It is one of the potential sites for abscess formation, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

 

Explanation:

 

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma.
  • Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair.
  • The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside.
  • Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing.
  • Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications.
  • Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months: This duration of abstinence is too short for the proper healing of the surgical site. Additionally, avoiding pregnancy for only 6 months might not provide sufficient time for the repair to gain adequate strength.

 

Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year: While the recommendation to avoid pregnancy for a year is appropriate, 6 weeks of sexual abstinence may still be insufficient for optimal healing of the fistula repair.

 

Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years: This recommendation is excessively long. While prolonged abstinence can prevent complications, a 6-month period is more than what is typically necessary. Similarly, avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is overly cautious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should be advised to abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year to ensure proper healing and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the sign shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double target sign

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the double target sign (also called target sign, halo sign, or double ring sign) which is seen in CSF rhinorrhoea. It is characterized by:

 

  • A central red spot (blood)
  • Surrounded by a peripheral halo (CSF)
  • This pattern appears when CSF mixed with blood drips onto filter paper or cloth
  • Commonly seen in traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea where blood is mixed with cerebrospinal fluid

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Radiological finding seen in blow-out fractures of orbit
  • Not related to CSF rhinorrhea

 

 

Option C. Beta 2 transferrin sign

 

  • This is not a visual sign but a laboratory test
  • Used to confirm the presence of CSF in nasal discharge
  • Tests for beta 2 transferrin which is specific to CSF

 

Option D. Handkerchief sign

 

  • Test where nasal discharge is placed on handkerchief
  • CSF doesn't stiffen the handkerchief while mucus does
  • Used to differentiate CSF from nasal mucus

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF Rhinorrhea

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions causes increased GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased renal perfusion / RPF

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is the rate at which blood is filtered in the kidneys. Several factors can influence GFR, including arteriolar resistance, arteriolar dilation, hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule, and renal perfusion.

 

Increased renal perfusion / RPF: Increased renal perfusion (renal plasma flow) enhances the blood flow into the kidneys and consequently increases the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries. This increase in pressure promotes filtration and increases GFR. Therefore, increased renal perfusion leads to an increased GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Afferent arteriolar resistance: Increasing afferent arteriolar resistance constricts the inlet to the glomerulus, decreasing renal plasma flow and hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries, which reduces GFR.

 

Option B. Efferent arteriolar dilation: Dilation of the efferent arteriole reduces resistance to blood flow out of the glomerulus, lowering hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries and decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increased pressure in Bowman's capsule counteracts the filtration pressure, reducing the net filtration pressure and decreasing GFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased renal perfusion (renal plasma flow) increases the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries, thereby increasing the GFR

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the dermatological condition shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

The dermatological condition shown in the image is characterized by a photosensitive rash. This type of rash typically occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the face, neck, and hands. The condition depicted is pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin). Pellagra is associated with the "4 Ds": diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis, and death. The dermatitis in pellagra is often photosensitive, meaning it worsens with exposure to sunlight, which explains the rash seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Deficiency in Vitamin A leads to conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia (dry eyes), not photosensitive rashes.

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine) causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not the skin.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C results in scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, and joint pain, but not typically photosensitive rashes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with a photosensitive rash among other symptoms like diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: Identify the mediastinal mass shown in the image. The measured Hounsfield unit in the mass revealed -70 HU. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teratoma

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) measurement of -70 indicates that the mass contains fat, as fat typically has an HU range between -10 and -100. The presence of negative HU values suggests that the mass is darker than water, which has an HU of zero. Among the listed options, teratomas are known to contain macroscopic fat and calcifications, which are characteristic features. These findings align with the imaging characteristics of teratomas, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymoma: Thymomas usually appear as soft tissue masses without fat content and do not typically exhibit negative HU values. They lack the calcification and macroscopic fat seen in teratomas.

 

Option B. PTH adenoma: Parathyroid (PTH) adenomas are soft tissue lesions usually found in the neck region and do not exhibit fat-containing characteristics or negative HU values on imaging.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: Lymphomas typically present as homogenous, soft tissue masses without fat content or calcifications. They also do not show negative HU values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative Hounsfield Unit values (between -10 to -100) indicate the presence of fat within a lesion, suggesting that the mass could be a teratoma, especially when accompanied by calcifications.

questions.text: A lady presents to the hospital after having a fight with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her health status. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) La belle indifférence

 

This case presents classic features of la belle indifférence, which is a characteristic finding in Conversion Disorder:

 

  • Neurological symptom (inability to speak)
  • Normal neurological examination
  • Lack of concern about the symptoms (characteristic of la belle indifférence)
  • Clear psychological stressor (fight with husband) 
    La belle indifférence refers to a paradoxical lack of concern about serious symptoms, typically seen in conversion disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malingering: Incorrect because malingering involves conscious faking of symptoms for external benefits (like financial gain or avoiding work). Here, the symptoms developed after an emotional stressor and the patient shows a characteristic lack of concern rather and there is no evidence given for intentional deception.

 

Option C. Somatic symptom disorder: Incorrect because in somatic symptom disorder, patients are typically extremely concerned and preoccupied with their symptoms, unlike this patient who shows lack of concern (la belle indifférence).

 

Option D. Generalised Anxiety Disorder: Incorrect because GAD presents with excessive anxiety and worry about various life circumstances, not with specific neurological symptoms. The lack of anxiety about symptoms also makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

La belle indifférence is a characteristic feature of conversion disorder, and is marked by paradoxical lack of concern about serious symptoms, typically occurring after psychological stressors.

 

Comparison of Somatic and Related Disorders

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a smoker patient who presented as shown in the given image and the next investigation required in the management of this patient?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythroplakia and Biopsy

 

The image shows a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa of a smoker. This presentation is characteristic of erythroplakia. Erythroplakia is known to have a high risk of malignant transformation, making it a precancerous lesion. Given its potential for developing into oral cancer, the next step in management is to perform a biopsy. A biopsy will allow for histopathological examination to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma, which is critical for guiding further treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia and observation: Observation alone is not appropriate for erythroplakia due to its high risk of malignancy. A biopsy is necessary to assess the lesion.

 

Option C. Leukoplakia and Biopsy: Leukoplakia is characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes, which is not consistent with the red lesion shown in the image.

 

Option D. Leukoplakia and observation: Similar to option C, leukoplakia refers to white patches, and observation alone is not recommended for high-risk lesions without first performing a biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythroplakia presents as a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa and has a high risk of malignant transformation. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a biopsy to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma.

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores

 

This is the most likely cause. Folate and vitamin B12 (cobalamin) are interconnected in various metabolic pathways. Folate supplementation can correct the hematologic manifestations of a B12 deficiency, but it does not address the neurologic manifestations. In some cases, folate therapy can "mask" the anemia associated with B12 deficiency, potentially aggravating the neurologic symptoms. The correct approach is to identify and treat the underlying B12 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malabsorption of folate: Malabsorption of folate could lead to a deficiency, but in this case, the patient was given folate (B9) supplementation, and the blood picture improved. This suggests that the issue is not with the absorption of folate but with its utilization.

 

Option B. Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency: While this is a consideration, especially in cases of neuropathy, the patient's symptoms worsening after folate supplementation suggest another mechanism.

 

Option C. Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS: This is not a recognized mechanism. Folate reductase is an enzyme that converts folate to its active form, and CNS deficiency of this enzyme is not a common cause of neurologic manifestations in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage.

 

The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.

 

Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which one of the following proteins in smooth muscle contraction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calmodulin

 

In smooth muscle cells, calcium plays a crucial role in initiating muscle contraction, similar to its role in skeletal muscle cells. However, the proteins that interact with calcium to start the contraction process are different in these two muscle types.

 

In skeletal muscle cells, calcium binds to troponin, which is part of the troponin-tropomyosin complex that regulates the interaction of actin and myosin, leading to muscle contraction. However, in smooth muscle cells, the contraction mechanism does not involve troponin.

 

In smooth muscle, when calcium ions enter the cell, they bind to a protein called calmodulin. This calcium-calmodulin complex then activates an enzyme called myosin light chain kinase (MLCK). Activated MLCK phosphorylates the myosin light chains, leading to conformational changes in myosin heads that allow them to interact with actin filaments, thereby causing muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a structural protein that forms filaments and interacts with myosin during muscle contraction. However, calcium does not bind directly to actin in smooth muscle to initiate contraction.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is a regulatory protein associated with actin filaments, but in smooth muscle, it does not play the same role in calcium binding as it does in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. Troponin: Troponin is the protein to which calcium binds in skeletal muscle to initiate contraction. However, troponin is absent in smooth muscle, so it cannot be the correct answer for smooth muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In smooth muscle cells, calcium binds to calmodulin to initiate muscle contraction, unlike in skeletal muscle where calcium binds to troponin.
